text:
Hello, welcome to
'This is My Architecture.'

Today we are with
Mikel Coira Murga,

who is Head of 
Artificial Intelligence Platforms
at Telefónica Tech AI of Things.

-Welcome, Mikel.
-Thank you so much.
It's a pleasure being here.
What exactly do you do
at Telefónica Tech AI of Things?
Well, it's the union of our areas,

the internet of things
and artificial intelligence,

to be able to take  
a combined proposal to clients.

Today we're going to talk
about one of your solutions,
called AI Suite.
What is AI Suite?

Well, despite what we constantly see
in the media,

that businesses should use
artificial intelligence,

the reality is that most
don't have the equipment
or the training to be able to use
machine learning models.

Plus, their business areas
can't exploit them.

Those two problems are the ones
AI Suite can solve.

Let's go deeper
into the architecture.

How have you evolved
over the last few years?

Well, AI Suite started
as a group of libraries
and tools to accelerate our
data consultation projects, right?
And little by little
it has evolved into a platform.
And that's the time to start to simplify
our operations,

and accelerate
our developments through

the adoption of self-managed
services from AWS.
Very interesting.

How have you been able
to scale that architecture

to be able to manage
all those user accounts,
those user environments?
Well, our clients
deposit their most valuable

asset in our accounts,
which is the data,

and what we do is,
within our organization,

we create an AWS account
for each user.

The way to supply
those accounts is via
the Service Catalog.

But of course,
as these accounts
increase, we need
to be able to manage them.

And that's where
the Control Tower comes into play.

Plus, it allows us to establish
the security guides
through guardrails.

How are you able to scale
and at the same time,
preserve the security of the information
for each one of your clients?

Well, in addition
to assigning the account,

later, when a client
stores information, they do it

in an S3 bucket,
which is assigned,
and that information is encrypted to REST.
Plus, everything having to do with
data processing is done

in infrastructures
that are created each time
that the client executes a task,
built according to the size
of the data that will be used.

Very interesting.
You talked about services
that are built for each account,

for each client,
and here we see AWS Glue and Amazon
and EMR.
How do they complement each other?
When do you use each one of them?

We have a very large
a database of codes
from the onset,

and we have
the experience of executing
tasks in EMR, right?

What happens, since
we already said we are undergoing

an evolution toward
self-managed services,

so everything having
to do with transformation

of datasets
and data profiling,
we're moving that to Glue.

And I understand that this whole environment 
of accounts will be complemented

with a backend
within your architecture.

What architecture
do you have for that layer?
That being, our system's backend

is an application in a node
that we put into
a container.

So, ECS
is the perfect companion

to be able to
deploy those containers
without having to worry
about managing the machines,

plus, when we incorporate
an Application Load Balancer,
we can make this elastic

and we can provide service
to all the requests that enter.
Perfect. And from that backend,
what types of data storage service

do you use
to preserve that information?
Well, we talked about our groups
of raw and transformed data
in an S3, however,

there is much more information,
like statistics on that data,

the algorithms
and hyperparameters
that we have used to train,
or even the user information.

All that information
is stored in DocumentDB,

which is in JSON format,
being very flexible, providing us
the agility we want for development.

On the other hand, we finally have
a bunch of deployed containers,

and on certain occasions
we need to coordinate them.

In that case we use
the native characteristics

of Redis, in this case,
to create

publication-subscription
queues,

and their native integration
with Socket.IO.

This vision of AI Suite
is very interesting.

How do you plan to evolve
the architecture in the future?
We have three open fronts.
The first is to keep migrating to

self-managed services,
so, for example,

all the user management,
we want to take to Cognito,

all the data transformation,
we want to take to DataBrew.

But there's another front,
which is how to keep increasing
the functionality of the platform,
enriching the models with data.

That's where
Redshift Spectrum or Athena
come into play, for example.

And lastly,
we also want to grow
the business and reach more clients,

and for that we are
using AWS Marketplace.
Thank you, Mikel, for sharing your
AI Suite experiences with us.
Thank you.

And thank you
to everyone for joining
'This is My Architecture.'
